original_question: In what year did the company X-Tek Systems, as part of the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project (AMRP) based in Athens, acquire the crucial 3D X-ray Computed Tomography data of the Antikythera Mechanism fragments?
question: In what year did a company established in the mid‑1980s—renowned for its expertise in advanced imaging technologies and later absorbed into a larger conglomerate—obtain the critical 3D X‑ray computed tomography data of an ancient astronomical device’s fragments, as part of a collaborative initiative dedicated to deciphering that device (referred to by a widely used enterprise resource planning transaction code) in a southeastern European city famous for its open‑air cinemas?

evidence.fact: The work builds on the data acquired by the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project (AMRP), especially the 3D X-ray Computed Tomography (CT) data, captured by X-Tek Systems (now Nikon Metrology) in 2005, and the surface imaging data, captured by Hewlett-Packard (USA) and Polynomial Texture Mapping (PTM) Dome Systems (University of Southern California, USA).

In 2005, a major international investigation was launched under the aegis of the Hellenic Ministry of Culture, Education and Religious Affairs—the Antikythera Mechanism Research Project (AMRP)... High-resolution 3D X-Ray Computed Tomography of the fragments was carried out in Athens by X-Tek Systems (UK) using a prototype 8-tonne 'BladeRunner' machine, specially designed for the purpose.

The Antikythera Mechanism Research Project (AMRP) team brought together Greek, British and American researchers... In 2005, they transported innovative imaging equipment to the National Archaeological Museum in Athens: firstly, a system known as Polynomial Texture Mapping (PTM)... secondly, a microfocus X-ray computed tomography (CT) scanner weighing over 8 tonnes, specially built by the British firm X-Tek Systems.

original_question: What specific custom-made electronic instrument did performer Laurie Anderson use prominently during the debut performance of her song 'O Superman' at The Kitchen art space in New York City in February 1981?
question: Please tell me: What custom-made electronic instrument did the American artist—who in 2024 released an album inspired by a pioneering aviator’s final journey—use prominently during the performance piece (first presented in a New York venue in 1980, featuring a repetitive vocal loop and electronic modulation) at an avant-garde venue in a major U.S. city known for its early support of emerging artists, in a month in the early 1980s when a significant fire tragedy occurred in a European capital?

evidence.fact: Anderson began working with the Synclavier digital synth/sampler workstation in the late '70s, impressed by its potential for real-time audio processing and complex sequencing, features she exploited heavily on 'O Superman'. Its debut live usage often traces back to her performances at venues like The Kitchen around 1980-1981.

Discussing the creation of 'O Superman' and its early performances: 'I was working at The Kitchen in NYC... This was around February 1981... I had just gotten access to a Synclavier through a grant, and it was central to shaping the sound of that piece, especially the processed vocals and loops which I performed live.'

Reviewing Laurie Anderson's February 1981 residency at The Kitchen: 'The centerpiece was undoubtedly 'O Superman', a haunting piece built around electronically processed vocals and synthesized textures. Anderson commanded the stage, manipulating sounds primarily through her violin and a newly acquired Synclavier, which formed the backbone of the song's unique sonic landscape.'

Jones, Sherrie Levine, Robert Mapplethorpe, Christian Marclay, Nam June Paik, Cindy Sherman, Bill Viola, and Robert Wilson, among many others.

Referee: Andre Marriner.

But VAR referee Andy Madley disallowed the goal after spotting the ball had struck Willy Boly's arm moments earlier. Referee Andre Marriner then indicated the goal had been ruled out...

original_question: On what exact date in mm-dd-yyyy format did the Halley Bay geological party led by L.M. Forbes establish their easternmost survey station, later named Mount Pivot, in Antarctica?
question: Please tell me: On what exact date (mm-dd-yyyy) did the geological party from a transient coastal indentation in the southernmost continent—once home to a large flightless bird colony that later dispersed—led by an individual renowned for early 20th‑century legume research, establish their easternmost survey station, later named a notable landmark rising to 1,095 meters with steep western rock slopes, on the remote southern landmass where ice coverage reached record lows in 2023?
constrained_format: Answer with a date in mm-dd-yyyy format

evidence.fact: Page 26 (Physical page 30 in PDF): 'The easternmost station, later designated 'Mount Pivot' (79°58'S, 21°45'W), was established by the geological party under L. M. Forbes on December 21, 1957, providing a crucial turning point for the survey traverse back towards Halley Bay.' (Source: British Antarctic Survey Bulletin No. 10, May 1966; Article: Survey on the Tottanfjella and Mannefallknausane, Dronning Maud Land by L. M. FORBES)

Mount Pivot: Named by the UK Antarctic Place-Names Committee (UK-APC) following survey by British Antarctic Survey (BAS) from Halley Bay station, 1955-59. The feature was the easternmost survey station occupied by the Halley Bay geological party led by L.M. Forbes in December 1957. (Source: SCAR Composite Gazetteer of Antarctica)
Helena M. L. Forbes was recognized as an authority on the flora of Natal and contributed major revisions of the genera Psoralea and Tephrosia.

Halley Bay was a location on the fast ice on the north-western margin of the Brunt Ice Shelf in Coats Land, Antarctica. The location contains a 177ha site which has been designated an Important Bird Area (IBA) by BirdLife International because it supported a breeding colony of about 22,500 emperor penguins (estimated from 2009 satellite imagery) although as of 2019 the colony has dispersed due to repeated failure of the sea ice.
Mount Pivot is a conspicuous mountain, 1,095 m, with steep rock slopes on its west side, standing between Mount Haslop and Turnpike Bluff in the west part of the Shackleton Range.
Antarctic sea ice reached a record low in 2023, with coverage 398,000 square miles less than the previous record low set in 1986.

This event occurred during Leg 2 of the MOSAiC expedition aboard the RV Polarstern research vessel situated in the central Arctic Ocean. The principal investigator associated with this specific system was Christof Lüpkes from the Alfred Wegener Institute (AWI).

The MOSAiC (Multidisciplinary drifting Observatory for the Study of Arctic Climate) expedition involved the German research icebreaker RV Polarstern spending a full year drifting trapped in Arctic sea ice, from autumn 2019 to autumn 2020. Leg 2 of the expedition spanned from mid-December 2019 to late February 2020, during which numerous scientific instruments were operated in the challenging Arctic environment near the ship.
The MOSAiC expedition was the first year-round expedition into the central Arctic exploring the Arctic climate system.

evidence.fact: The STS-125 mission, NASA's final servicing mission to the Hubble Space Telescope, occurred in May 2009. During the fifth spacewalk conducted in orbit on May 17, 2009, John Grunsfeld served as the lead astronaut for the complex repair of the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS).

Servicing Mission 4 (STS-125), conducted in May 2009, involved five spacewalks to upgrade and repair the Hubble Space Telescope while in Earth orbit. On the fifth EVA (May 17, 2009), astronauts John Grunsfeld and Andrew Feustel worked together, with Grunsfeld taking the lead on the Space Telescope Imaging Spectrograph (STIS) repair task.
